Abstract: This article explores the evolving landscape of firearms law and scholarship, moving beyond traditional focuses on violence and mortality. It examines the complex interplay between the Second Amendment, self-defense rights, and broader societal implications of gun ownership. The study analyzes recent legal developments, court decisions, and academic discourse to provide a comprehensive overview of current trends in firearms legislation and research. By considering cultural, economic, and political factors alongside legal arguments, the article offers a nuanced perspective on the multifaceted nature of gun rights and regulations in contemporary society. This interdisciplinary approach aims to contribute to a more holistic understanding of firearms law, fostering informed debate and policy-making in this contentious field.
